measured_by: "How satisfying is A as an explanation for B?" 0–10 Likert rating
justification: In Study 1A, participants were asked, “To what extent do you think that A is a satisfying explanation for why B happened?” on a scale from 0 (Not at all satisfying) to 10 (Very satisfying), providing a direct quantitative measure of explanatory power.

measured_by: "How strong is the causal relationship between A and B?" 1–9 Likert rating
justification: Study 1B (and later Studies 2A/2B) asked, “How strong do you think this causal relationship is…?” with responses made on a 1 (Extremely Weak) to 9 (Extremely Strong) scale, operationalising perceived causal strength.

Before rating strength in Studies 2A and 2B, participants answered a yes/no question such as, “Do you think that Randy having Ferraro’s Disorder caused him to lose hair?”—a dichotomous measure of whether they endorsed the causal link’s existence.

measured_by: −5 to 5 forced-choice scale selecting which of two math statements remained true after a hypothetical change
justification: In Study 4, participants judged which of two mathematically equivalent statements stayed true after Prospero’s spell, responding on a scale from −5 to 5; these ratings captured the perceived counterfactual robustness of each statement.

After the main task in Study 4, “Numeracy (Lipkus et al., 2001) was then measured for exploratory purposes,” indicating use of the established Lipkus Numeracy Scale to assess participants’ numerical ability.
